articles.headline: U.S. Sets Coronavirus Case Record Amid New Surge
articles.snippet: More than 85,000 new cases of the virus were reported across the country on Friday, shattering an earlier single-day record and stirring new fears about the months ahead.
articles.abstract: More than 85,000 new cases of the virus were reported across the country on Friday, shattering an earlier single-day record and stirring new fears about the months ahead.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Edgar Sandoval, Lucy Tompkins and Simon Romero

articles.headline: Oil Industry Expresses Concern, Not Alarm, About Biden Comments
articles.snippet: After the candidate called for a “transition” away from oil and gas, executives said the country would need fossil fuels for decades to come.
articles.abstract: After the candidate called for a “transition” away from oil and gas, executives said the country would need fossil fuels for decades to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s promise that he would “transition” the country away from oil and natural gas might hurt him politically in Texas and Pennsylvania, but it did not come as a surprise to many in the energy industry.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Paid Time Off, Free Fries: How Corporate America Is Getting Out the Vote
articles.snippet: Spurred by recent social unrest, many U.S. companies are trying to make it easier for workers, and urging their customers, to cast their ballots.
articles.abstract: Spurred by recent social unrest, many U.S. companies are trying to make it easier for workers, and urging their customers, to cast their ballots.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America is offering employees up to three hours of paid time to vote this year. The spirits company Diageo North America has declared a no-meeting day on Nov. 3. Best Buy is closing stores until noon that day, and PayPal is offering a half day, paid, to workers who volunteer at polling places.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Trump’s Philanthropy: Big Tax Write-Offs and Claims That Don’t Always Add Up
articles.snippet: Hidden financial records cast doubt on a number of his charitable commitments and show that most of his giving came from land deals that offset his income.
articles.abstract: Hidden financial records cast doubt on a number of his charitable commitments and show that most of his giving came from land deals that offset his income.
articles.lead_paragraph: In President Trump’s telling, he is a committed philanthropist with strong ties to many charities. “If you don’t give back, you’re never ever going to be fulfilled in life,” he wrote in “Trump 101: The Way to Success,” published at the height of his “Apprentice” fame.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig, Russ Buettner and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: She Used to Clean City Hall. Now, She Runs It.
articles.snippet: In Russia, elections are typically theatrical affairs with the winner and loser preordained. Sometimes, though, they go off script.
articles.abstract: In Russia, elections are typically theatrical affairs with the winner and loser preordained. Sometimes, though, they go off script.
articles.lead_paragraph: POVALIKHINO, Russia — With election day looming, Nikolai Loktev was in a panic: The mayor of a tiny village of log houses, wood-burning stoves and rutted dirt roads 300 miles east of Moscow, he was running for re-election unopposed.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Trump’s Biggest Economic Legacy Isn’t About the Numbers
articles.snippet: The president has shifted the way both parties talk about trade, immigration and deficits — and despite dismal economic news, many voters still reward him for it.
articles.abstract: The president has shifted the way both parties talk about trade, immigration and deficits — and despite dismal economic news, many voters still reward him for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — To understand how much President Trump has altered the conversation around the economy, just listen to Bruce Haines, who spent decades as an executive at U.S. Steel before becoming a managing partner of the elegant Historic Hotel Bethlehem.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: The White Issue: Has Anna Wintour’s Diversity Push Come Too Late?
articles.snippet: Vogue’s September issue celebrated Black culture and contributors. But some employees say the magazine’s powerful editor fostered a workplace that sidelined women of color.
articles.abstract: Vogue’s September issue celebrated Black culture and contributors. But some employees say the magazine’s powerful editor fostered a workplace that sidelined women of color.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vogue’s September issue was different this year. Anna Wintour and her staff put it together when more than 15 million people were marching in Black Lives Matter protests nationwide and employees at Vogue’s parent company, Condé Nast, were publicly calling out what they viewed as racism in their own workplace. At 316 pages, the issue, titled “Hope,” featured a majority of Black artists, models and photographers, a first for the magazine.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee

articles.headline: How The Epoch Times Created a Giant Influence Machine
articles.snippet: Since 2016, the Falun Gong-backed newspaper has used aggressive Facebook tactics and right-wing misinformation to create an anti-China, pro-Trump media empire.
articles.abstract: Since 2016, the Falun Gong-backed newspaper has used aggressive Facebook tactics and right-wing misinformation to create an anti-China, pro-Trump media empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, The Epoch Times was a small, low-budget newspaper with an anti-China slant that was handed out free on New York street corners. But in 2016 and 2017, the paper made two changes that transformed it into one of the country’s most powerful digital publishers.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose

articles.headline: Joe Biden Had Close Ties With Police Leaders. Will They Help Him Now?
articles.snippet: His proposed solution to addressing both urgent calls for police reform and animosity from law enforcement toward Democrats is one he’s long relied on: He’ll just get everyone in the same room.
articles.abstract: His proposed solution to addressing both urgent calls for police reform and animosity from law enforcement toward Democrats is one he’s long relied on: He’ll just get everyone in the same room.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Johnson knew, before he reached out to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign last spring, that things had changed between the former vice president and the nation’s police unions. A once-close alliance had frayed amid clashes over police brutality and racism in the justice system. Still, Mr. Johnson, the executive director of the National Association of Police Organizations, invited Mr. Biden to address the group as it weighed its 2020 endorsement.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Apple, Google and a Deal That Controls the Internet
articles.snippet: In a landmark antitrust complaint, the Justice Department is targeting a secretive partnership that is worth billions of dollars to both companies.
articles.abstract: In a landmark antitrust complaint, the Justice Department is targeting a secretive partnership that is worth billions of dollars to both companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai, the chief executives of Apple and Google, were photographed eating dinner together in 2017 at an upscale Vietnamese restaurant called Tamarine, the picture set off a tabloid-worthy frenzy about the relationship between the two most powerful companies in Silicon Valley.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Pope Francis Appoints First African-American Cardinal
articles.snippet: Wilton Gregory, the archbishop of Washington, was among 13 new cardinals named on Sunday.
articles.abstract: Wilton Gregory, the archbishop of Washington, was among 13 new cardinals named on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pope Francis on Sunday named Wilton Gregory, the archbishop of Washington, a cardinal, elevating the first African-American to the Catholic church’s highest governing body, a groundbreaking act in a year when demands for racial justice have consumed the country.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: Schools Clamored for Seesaw’s App. That Was Good News, and Bad News.
articles.snippet: It wasn’t simple to become a do-it-all education tool almost overnight.
articles.abstract: It wasn’t simple to become a do-it-all education tool almost overnight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first requests that upended Seesaw, a popular classroom app, came in January from teachers and education officials abroad. Their schools were shutting down because of the coronavirus, and they urgently wanted the app adjusted for remote learning. The company figured it could do that with a single short hackathon project.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Kodak Loan Debacle Puts a New Agency in the Hot Seat
articles.snippet: A stumbling effort to prop up the domestic generic drugs sector underscores the challenges of a Trump administration industrial policy.
articles.abstract: A stumbling effort to prop up the domestic generic drugs sector underscores the challenges of a Trump administration industrial policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a virtual conference in September, Adam Boehler, chief executive of the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation, described his nascent agency as a bulwark against China’s “economic colonialism” — with $60 billion in annual lending authority to counter Beijing’s strategy of spreading its global influence with low-interest infrastructure loans.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Ana Swanson and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: A Voting Rights Battle in a School Board ‘Coup’
articles.snippet: For Black residents of Sumter County, the fight for representation echoed the civil rights era. For white residents, it reflected the anxiety, made manifest by the Trump era, of maintaining power over institutions even without the votes to do so.
articles.abstract: For Black residents of Sumter County, the fight for representation echoed the civil rights era. For white residents, it reflected the anxiety, made manifest by the Trump era, of maintaining power over institutions even without the votes to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMERICUS, Ga. — One mother worked at Habitat for Humanity. The other helped teenagers who had run afoul of the law. Their sons played soccer together, and for a few years, the two women also sat on the county school board.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: Trump Had One Last Story to Sell. The Wall Street Journal Wouldn’t Buy It.
articles.snippet: Inside the White House’s secret, last-ditch effort to change the narrative, and the election — and the return of the media gatekeepers.
articles.abstract: Inside the White House’s secret, last-ditch effort to change the narrative, and the election — and the return of the media gatekeepers.
articles.lead_paragraph: By early October, even people inside the White House believed President Trump’s re-election campaign needed a desperate rescue mission. So three men allied with the president gathered at a house in McLean, Va., to launch one.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: The Two Americas Financing the Trump and Biden Campaigns
articles.snippet: For the first time, data reveals not only when Joe Biden overtook President Trump in the money race, but also what parts of the country powered his surge.
articles.abstract: For the first time, data reveals not only when Joe Biden overtook President Trump in the money race, but also what parts of the country powered his surge.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time, data reveals not only when Joe Biden overtook President Trump in the money race, but also what parts of the country powered his surge.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Ella Koeze, Rachel Shorey and Lazaro Gamio

articles.headline: Infection of Pence Aides Raises New Questions About Trump’s Virus Response
articles.snippet: From the beginning, the president has turned mask wearing and other preventive measures into a loyalty test. He and his aides have taken the same approach inside the White House.
articles.abstract: From the beginning, the president has turned mask wearing and other preventive measures into a loyalty test. He and his aides have taken the same approach inside the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Black Senate Candidates in the South Tell Democrats to ‘Meet the Moment’
articles.snippet: Several Black Democrats are running competitively in conservative states, and they are doing so by talking explicitly about race.
articles.abstract: Several Black Democrats are running competitively in conservative states, and they are doing so by talking explicitly about race.
articles.lead_paragraph: HORN LAKE, Miss. — Mike Espy and Jaime Harrison, two of the five Black Senate candidates in the South this year, may belong to different political generations, but they both came up in a Democratic Party where African-American politicians didn’t talk directly about race in campaigns against white opponents.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: How the Virus Slowed the Booming Wind Energy Business
articles.snippet: Renewable energy developers have struggled to finish projects as the pandemic disrupts construction and global supply chains.
articles.abstract: Renewable energy developers have struggled to finish projects as the pandemic disrupts construction and global supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as businesses around the world shut down this spring, executives at EDF Renewables were hopeful they would finish installing 99 wind turbines in southern Nebraska before a year-end deadline. Then, in early April, the pandemic dealt a big blow to the company.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Walker Pickering

articles.headline: Colleges Slash Budgets in the Pandemic, With ‘Nothing Off-Limits’
articles.snippet: Liberal arts departments, graduate student aid and even tenured teaching positions are targets as the coronavirus causes shortfalls.
articles.abstract: Liberal arts departments, graduate student aid and even tenured teaching positions are targets as the coronavirus causes shortfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the coronavirus pandemic here.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: They Did Not Vote in 2016. Why They Plan to Skip the Election Again.
articles.snippet: Between a third and a half of all eligible voters typically stay home during presidential elections.
articles.abstract: Between a third and a half of all eligible voters typically stay home during presidential elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa. — Like nearly half of all the eligible voters in her county in 2016, Keyana Fedrick did not vote.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Ant Challenged Beijing and Prospered. Now It Toes the Line.
articles.snippet: The tech giant, which is preparing for a mega I.P.O., has transformed personal finance in China. Regulators have taken notice.
articles.abstract: The tech giant, which is preparing for a mega I.P.O., has transformed personal finance in China. Regulators have taken notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Jack Ma of Alibaba helped turn China into the world’s biggest e-commerce market over the past two decades, he was also vowing to pull off a more audacious transformation.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong and Cao Li
